title: Assembly Members sworn into office
text:
23:00 CET Assembly Members sworn into office By GNA 
Kasoa, Oct. 7, GNA - A total of 19 Assembly Members in Awutu Senya East, were on Tuesday sworn into office, with a call on them to serve their people in order to improve their living conditions, and make them part of the decision-making process and governance at the local level. 
The call was contained in the President's inaugural address delivered on his behalf by Ms. Barbra Serwah Asamoah, Deputy Minister for Land and Natural Resource, at the inauguration ceremony of the Second Municipal Assembly of the Fourth Republic held at the forecourt of the Awutu-Senya East Assembly Block at Kasoa. 
The Assembly Members were made up of 13 elected and 6 appointees 
Ms. Felicia Gandedzi, Awutu-Senya East Municipal Magistrate Court Judge, took them through the oaths of office and secrecy, and swore them into office. 
The Deputy Minister said the role of Assembly Member was very crucial, and as they had accepted to explain polices for a better understanding to the ordinary Ghanaian in a participatory democracy adopted by the country, they should maintain close contacts with the electorates. 
She urged them to consult on issues to be discussed in the Assembly, collate their views and opinions for presentation to the Assembly as the Local Government Act of 1993 outlined some of their duties. 
'You are therefore required to have due regard to the national interest and the interest of the entire people in the Municipality, hence you should work for the public good and not for personal interest,' she said. 
She congratulated them on their election and appointment as Assemble Members, which she said was a mark of confidence the people had reposed in them. 
When the Assembly was served by dedicated and committed individuals who made it their duty to demand accountability of themselves and management of the Assemblies, then the credibility of the Assembly would be assured in respect of decision-making and delivery of service to the people, she added. 
Abokuadi Wyettey Agyemang Otabil the second, Paramount Chief of Awutu-Bereku, who chaired the ceremony asked the new assembly members to see themselves as one people with a common goal to forge ahead and help develop the area. 
Later, the members failed to elect a Presiding member after voting two rounds in an election conducted by officials from the Municipal Electoral Commission led by Mr. Dominic Agbanu, the Municipal Electoral Officer. 
The contest was between Mr Jocab Alanga, Assemblyman for New Town, and Mr Bernard Ayeh Dankwa, Walantu-CP-Top Hill Assemblyman, with none of them obtaining the two-thirds majority. 
The election of a Presiding Member was therefore postponed. 
GNA
